title: Security Policies, Rules and Protocols
author: UnknownServr
body:
Generate me a document of the security policies, rules and protocol of the company:
Comprehensive Security Policy for Vortex SDR Bhd
1. Introduction
1.1 Purpose
This document establishes the security policies, rules, and protocols to protect the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of Vortex SDR Bhd's data, assets, and infrastructure.
1.2 Scope
This policy applies to all employees, contractors, vendors, and third-party service providers who interact with Vortex SDR Bhd's IT systems, facilities, and data.

2. Information Security Policy
2.1	User Access Control
	Role-Based Access Control (RBAC):
-	Access to systems, applications, and data is granted based on an employee's job function.
-	Permissions are categorized into standard user, privileged user, and administrator levels.
-	Access requests must be approved by department heads and the IT security team.
	Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA):
-	All administrative systems (e.g., servers, databases, financial applications) require MFA.
-	Employees accessing sensitive data remotely must authenticate via VPN with MFA.
-	In case of a failed authentication attempt, users are required to verify their identity through an alternative method (e.g., security questions, one-time passcodes).
	Access Logs & Monitoring:
-	All system and network access is logged and monitored.
-	Weekly access log reviews are conducted by the IT security team to detect anomalies such as unauthorized logins or privilege escalations.
-	Unauthorized access attempts trigger an automatic alert to the security team.
	Account Deactivation:
-	Employee accounts are deactivated immediately upon resignation, termination, or prolonged inactivity (more than 90 days).
-	IT security conducts quarterly audits to remove redundant user accounts.
2.2 Data Classification & Handling
All company data is classified into four categories, with specific handling procedures for each.
•	Public:
-	Includes marketing materials, product catalogs, and general announcements.
-	Can be shared publicly with no security restrictions.

•	Restricted:
-	Includes non-sensitive business data, such as customer purchase history and transaction records. 
-	Can only be accessed by authorized employees within relevant departments. 
-	Stored on secured internal servers with limited access.

•	Sensitive:
-	Includes personally identifiable information (PII) of customers and employees (e.g., names, addresses, contact details).
-	Access is restricted to authorized personnel (HR, finance, customer support).
-	Must be encrypted both at rest and in transit using AES-256 encryption.
-	Cannot be transmitted over unencrypted email or stored on personal devices.

•	Confidential:
-	Includes company financial reports, vendor contracts, legal documents, and trade secrets.
-	Only top management and authorized personnel have access.
-	Must be stored in encrypted databases with strict access controls.
-	Sharing outside the company requires approval from the legal and security teams.

•	Encryption & Data Protection:
-	All sensitive and confidential data must be encrypted before storage or transmission.
-	Emails containing confidential data must be encrypted using company-approved email security tools.
-	Portable storage devices containing sensitive data must be password-protected and encrypted.

2.3 IT Asset Usage
To ensure the security and integrity of IT assets, employees must adhere to the following policies:
•	Security Configuration:
-	Employees must not disable antivirus, firewall, or endpoint protection software.
-	IT security periodically audits and enforces system security settings.
•	Data Sharing & Transfer:
-	Unauthorized copying, emailing, or uploading of company data to third-party services (e.g., personal cloud storage) is strictly prohibited.
-	Secure company-approved file-sharing services must be used for data transfers.
•	Business Use Only:
-	Company-owned computers, laptops, and mobile devices must only be used for official business purposes.
-	Personal use of company devices (e.g., streaming, gaming, social media) is restricted to prevent exposure to malware and unauthorized data leaks.
•	Removable Media & External Devices:
-	USB drives, external hard disks, and memory cards are restricted unless approved by IT security.
-	Employees must scan any external device for malware before use.
•	Internet & Email Usage:
-	Employees must not visit unauthorized websites that pose cybersecurity risks.
-	Phishing awareness training is conducted regularly to educate employees on email security threats.

2.4 Software & Installation Restrictions
Unauthorized software installations introduce security risks and compliance violations. The following policies apply:
•	Authorized Software Only:
-	Employees may only install software approved by the IT department.
-	Software installations require prior approval to ensure licensing and security compliance.
•	Prohibited Applications:
-	Unauthorized or pirated software is strictly prohibited.
-	IT security regularly scans company devices to detect and remove unapproved software.
•	Use of External Storage & Peripheral Devices:
-	The use of external USB devices is restricted to prevent data breaches and malware infections.
-	IT security maintains a list of approved external devices that can connect to the company network.

3. Network Security Policy
3.1 Firewall & Intrusion Detection System (IDS)
•  Firewall Implementation & Configuration:
-	A properly configured firewall must be deployed at all entry and exit points of the corporate network.
-	The firewall must enforce strict access controls, blocking unauthorized inbound and outbound traffic.
-	Firewall rules must be regularly updated based on new security threats.
•  Intrusion Detection & Prevention Systems (IDPS):
-	An Intrusion Detection System (IDS) must be deployed to monitor network traffic for suspicious activity.
-	An Intrusion Prevention System (IPS) must be configured to automatically block or mitigate detected threats.
-	The system should generate real-time alerts for security teams to respond to potential threats.
•  Security Log Monitoring & Review:
-	All firewall and IDS/IPS activity must be logged.
-	Security logs must be reviewed weekly for anomalies such as repeated failed login attempts, unusual data transfers, and unauthorized access attempts.
-	Any critical security incidents must be escalated to the IT security team for immediate investigation.
3.2 Virtual Private Network (VPN)
•	Secure VPN Usage:
o	Employees working remotely must connect through the company's VPN to ensure encrypted data transmission.
o	The VPN must use industry-standard encryption protocols, such as IPSec or OpenVPN.
•	Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) for VPN Access:
o	Employees must authenticate using multi-factor authentication (MFA) when connecting to the VPN.
o	Authentication methods include a combination of: 
	A password
	A one-time passcode (OTP) sent via SMS or an authenticator app
	A biometric verification (if supported)
•	Access Restrictions:
o	VPN access is restricted to authorized employees only.
o	The IT department must approve and maintain a list of authorized VPN users.
o	VPN sessions should automatically disconnect after a defined period of inactivity to prevent unauthorized access.
3.3 Wi-Fi Security
•  Separation of Networks:
-	Separate Wi-Fi networks must be maintained for: 
-	Employees (Internal Network) – Secure access to corporate systems.
-	Guests/Customers (Public Network) – Limited access to internet services only.
-	The customer/public Wi-Fi must be completely isolated from the internal company network to prevent unauthorized access.
•  Wi-Fi Authentication & Access Control:
-	Employee Wi-Fi access requires authentication using company credentials.
-	Employees must not share Wi-Fi credentials with unauthorized personnel.
-	Guest Wi-Fi must use a captive portal requiring temporary credentials for access.
•  Encryption & Security Protocols:
-	WPA3 encryption must be enforced on all company Wi-Fi networks to protect against eavesdropping and unauthorized access.
-	MAC address filtering should be used to restrict access to company-approved devices.
-	Wi-Fi access points must be configured to hide SSIDs for internal networks to prevent unauthorized scanning.

4. Terminal (Endpoint) Security Policy
4.1 Antivirus & Endpoint Protection
•	Mandatory Antivirus & EDR Deployment:
o	All employee workstations, servers, and company-issued devices must have up-to-date antivirus software installed.
o	An Endpoint Detection & Response (EDR) solution must be implemented to detect and respond to advanced threats in real time.
o	The antivirus and EDR software must be centrally managed by IT security teams to ensure compliance.
•	Automated Security Scans:
o	Daily automated scans must be scheduled on all company devices to identify and remove potential threats.
o	Any detected threats must be logged and reported to IT security teams for further investigation.
•	Real-Time Threat Monitoring & Response:
o	The security software must provide real-time protection against zero-day attacks, malware, and unauthorized software installations.
o	Suspicious activity must trigger immediate alerts, and appropriate incident response procedures must be followed.
4.2 Patch Management
•  Regular Security Updates:
-	Operating system and software security patches must be applied bi-weekly to ensure all systems remain protected.
-	Updates should be tested in a controlled environment before deployment to minimize the risk of software conflicts.
•  Critical Patch Deployment:
-	Critical security patches must be deployed within 24 hours of release to protect against known vulnerabilities.
-	Emergency patches addressing zero-day exploits must be applied immediately after validation.
•  Patch Compliance & Verification:
-	IT administrators must maintain a patch compliance report to track patch deployment status across all endpoints.
-	Security teams must conduct quarterly patch audits to ensure compliance with the patch management policy.
4.3 Device & Peripheral Controls
•  Company-Approved Devices Only:
Only company-authorized devices may connect to the internal network and critical systems.
All company devices must be registered with unique asset identification numbers for tracking.
•  Restriction of Personal Devices:
Personal laptops, USB drives, and mobile devices are strictly prohibited from connecting to critical business systems.
Employees must use company-provided devices for all work-related activities.
•  Peripheral Device Control:
USB ports, Bluetooth, and external storage devices must be disabled on sensitive systems unless explicitly approved by IT security teams.
Data transfer via external storage must be logged and monitored for compliance with security policies.
Any unauthorized device detected on the company network must trigger an automatic security alert.

5. Physical Security Policy
5.1 Access Control
•  Employee Identification & Badges:
All employees must wear company-issued ID badges at all times while on company premises.
ID badges must be displayed visibly and must not be shared with unauthorized individuals.
Employees must immediately report lost or stolen badges to security personnel.
•  Restricted Area Access:
Customers and visitors are strictly prohibited from entering sensitive or restricted areas, such as: 
Server rooms
Storage facilities
Employee-only workspaces
Any visitor requiring access must be escorted by authorized personnel and must sign an access log.
•  Secure Storage & Facility Access:
All storage areas, server rooms, and administrative offices must remain locked when not in use.
Access to secure areas must be granted only to authorized personnel based on job roles.
Keycards, biometric scanners, or security codes must be used to enhance access control.
5.2 Security Surveillance
•  CCTV Surveillance Requirements:
High-definition (HD) CCTV cameras must be installed at all entry points, hallways, storage areas, and transaction counters.
Cameras must be positioned to cover critical areas, ensuring no blind spots.
Security teams must monitor live footage to detect any suspicious activity.
•  Retention & Storage of Surveillance Footage:
CCTV recordings must be retained for a minimum of 30 days for investigative and security audit purposes.
Access to recorded footage is restricted to authorized personnel only (e.g., security officers, IT security teams, and company executives).
Surveillance systems must be protected against unauthorized tampering or deletion.
5.3 Incident Response
•  Incident Reporting Procedure:
Employees must immediately report any suspicious activity, unauthorized access attempts, or security breaches to the Security Department.
Security incidents must be documented in an Incident Report Log, including: 
Date and time of the incident
Description of the event
Actions taken and resolution status
•  Emergency Response Drills:
Quarterly security drills must be conducted to prepare employees for emergency situations, including: 
Fire evacuation drills
Active security threat response drills
Data breach response simulations
All employees must participate in these drills, and compliance must be documented.
•  Security Personnel & Emergency Contact Protocols:
A dedicated security team must be available on-site or on-call 24/7.
Employees must be aware of the emergency contact numbers and procedures to follow in case of a physical security breach.

6. Employee Awareness & Training
6.1 Security Training
•	New employees must complete security awareness training.
•	Annual refresher training is mandatory.
6.2 Simulated Security Drills
•	Periodic phishing simulations must be conducted.
•	Employees handling sensitive data must participate in advanced security workshops.

7. Compliance & Regulatory Policies
7.1 Regulatory Compliance
- The company must comply with ISO 27001, PCI DSS, GDPR, and other relevant standards.
- Regular security audits must be conducted.
7.2 Third-Party Security Compliance
- Vendors and service providers must adhere to security policies.
- Any third-party breach must be reported immediately.

8. Incident Response & Disaster Recovery
8.1 Incident Response Plan
- A formal incident response plan must be in place.
- Incidents must be categorized by severity.
8.2 Disaster Recovery Plan
- Data backup and disaster recovery plans must be tested quarterly.
- Critical business functions must have documented recovery steps.

9. Data Retention & Disposal Policy
9.1 Retention Guidelines
-	Customer and financial records must be retained for the legally required period.
-	Logs must be maintained for at least 6 months.
9.2 Secure Data Disposal
- Data must be securely erased before decommissioning devices.
- Paper records must be shredded before disposal.

10. Monitoring & Logging Policy
10.1 Security Monitoring
- Continuous monitoring must be implemented for critical systems.
- Anomaly detection tools must be deployed.

10.2 Logging Requirements
- Logs must be generated for all access to sensitive systems.
- Logs must be reviewed weekly.

11. Reporting & Enforcement
11.1 Violation Handling
-	Violations of security policies may result in disciplinary action, including termination.
-	Employees must report security concerns to the IT security team.

By implementing these security policies, Vortex SDR Bhd ensures a secure and compliant environment for all employees, customers, and business partners.
